name: Funchal
fun_fact: Fun fact: Funchal is the only place in the world where traditional wicker toboggan sleds (carros de cesto) are still used - two 'carreiros' in white uniforms push tourists downhill at 48 km/h on a 2km journey from Monte to Livramento. The tradition started in the 1850s as transportation for locals.

hero_dishes.name: Espetada
hero_dishes.description: Skewered beef chunks (traditionally from prime cuts) grilled over laurel wood, hung dramatically from hooks, served with bolo do caco (garlic bread)
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Madeiran specialty uses laurel wood (native to the island) for grilling, giving the meat a unique aromatic flavor. The beef skewers hang from special hooks above the table - a dramatic presentation. Traditionally eaten at festivals and celebrations, now served at every Madeiran restaurant. Locals argue whether to season with just salt or add garlic.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: O Celeiro in Funchal's Old Town, ArmazÃ©m do Sal (historic salt warehouse restaurant), or traditional Madeiran restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Lapas (Limpets)
hero_dishes.description: Grilled limpets (sea snails) served in their shells with garlic butter and lemon
hero_dishes.origin_story: These volcanic rock-clinging mollusks are Madeira's iconic seafood. Harvesting them from crashing Atlantic waves is dangerous work. The meat is chewy, briny, intensely oceanic. Locals eat them as appetizers with Coral beer. Prying them off rocks requires skill - they clamp down when disturbed.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Beachfront restaurants in Funchal, Restaurante do Forte, or seafood spots near the marina

hero_dishes.name: Bolo do Caco
hero_dishes.description: Flatbread cooked on a basalt stone slab, split open and slathered with garlic butter - served with almost everything
hero_dishes.origin_story: Caco refers to the flat basalt stone used for cooking. This sweet potato flatbread has been Madeiran staple for centuries. The garlic butter (manteiga de alho) is generous - bread glistening with it. Locals eat it with espetada, soup, or just by itself. The sweet potato gives subtle sweetness.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every restaurant in Funchal - it's mandatory with espetada, or bakeries throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Black Scabbard Fish (Espada Preta)
hero_dishes.description: Deep-sea fish with terrifying appearance, usually served fried with banana and passion fruit sauce - surprisingly delicious
hero_dishes.origin_story: This prehistoric-looking fish lives 800-1200 meters deep in Madeira's waters. Fishermen use special hooks on long lines. The fish is jet black with huge teeth - nightmare fuel. But the white flesh is delicate, mild, and flaky. Serving it with fried banana is uniquely Madeiran - sweet and savory combination works brilliantly.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurante do Forte, Santa Maria seafood restaurant, or traditional Madeiran restaurants in Funchal

signature_drinks.name: Madeira Wine
signature_drinks.description: Fortified wine aged in oak barrels, ranging from dry (Sercial) to sweet (Malmsey) - oxidized, complex, can age for centuries
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Madeira wine has been produced since the 1400s. The unique 'estufagem' aging process heats the wine, creating oxidized flavors that allow it to age indefinitely - bottles from the 1800s are still drinkable. Locals drink dry versions as aperitifs, sweet versions as dessert wine. Used in cooking traditional Madeiran dishes.

signature_drinks.name: Poncha
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Madeiran cocktail of aguardente (sugarcane distillate), honey, lemon juice, and sometimes passion fruit or other fruits
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Pronounced 'pon-shah,' this is Madeira's national drink. Originally fishermen's remedy for colds, now drunk recreationally. The aguardente is strong (40%+ alcohol), honey sweetens it, citrus balances. Locals drink it at poncha bars (tabernas) in Funchal's Old Town. Beware - it's deceptively strong.

food_culture_notes: Mercado dos Lavradores (Workers Market) is Funchal's vibrant market selling exotic fruits (custard apples, monstera deliciosa), fresh fish, and flowers
Madeira grows tropical fruits year-round due to mild climate - passionfruit, guavas, and bananas everywhere
Portuguese tradition of petiscos (small plates) is strong - lapas, bolo do caco, and pickles as bar snacks
Funchal's restaurants often have terraces with dramatic Atlantic Ocean or mountain views
